title: How does quit claiming a deed effect a bankruptcy?
question: My mother and I own our home together in California. We do not have a mortgage, as we bought the house with cash from a life insurance pay out. I have some credit card debt that I am having difficulty paying and would like to file Chapter 7 bankruptcy. Before doing so, I was hoping to quit claim my portion of the house to my mother, so that our home wouldn't be effected by the bankruptcy. How long after quit claiming, can I file for bankruptcy? Do I need to wait for a certain amount of time so that it doesn't look like I'm trying to hide assets? I am aware of California's homestead exemptions, but unfortunately my half of the house is worth more than the homestead exemption, and I want to make sure that the bankruptcy does not effect our home or the equity in it before proceeding with a bankruptcy.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy homestead exemption,Credit,Debt,Debt negotiation,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate documents,Real estate quitclaim deed,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers:
If you transfer a property prior to filing for Bankruptcy you have to disclose it in your bankruptcy petition. With such a transfer you can potentially loose the value of your exemptions and the trustee can potentially seek the sale of the house.

I strongly suggest that you seek consultation of an experienced Bankruptcy attorney prior to making such a transfer and filing for a Chapter 7 Bankruptcy. An experienced Bankruptcy attorney will be able to evaluate your situation thoroughly and propose an alternative resolution which will be in your best interests.

A Chapter 7 trustee has the power to undo ("clawback") preferential transfers and fraudulent conversions - essentially, when the debtor transfers property to someone else either to avoid paying creditors, or to play favorites among creditors. Transferring your interest in a house to a family member is a classic situation.

As far as how long after the transfer should you wait to file bankruptcy, the answer is a bit more complicated. Any transfers made within two years will be disclosed in your petition. However, California law provides a four year statute of limitations for fraudulent transfer actions, and an aggressive trustee might use this to proceed.

You should probably consult with an attorney familiar with the trustees in your area, and explore your Chapter 13 options, as well as Chapter 7.

As noted by other counsel, this is a bad idea unless you are going to wait to file. California has a "fraudulent conveyance" statute as well as does the Bankruptcy Code. I'm not sure what length the CA statute provides for, but it is longer than the one in the Bankruptcy Code, which as noted is 2 years.

The trustee in a bankruptcy can reverse the transfer of assets and recover them from the transferee if the transfer was within 2 years of the bankruptcy filing. No exemption can be claimed for the recovered property.

You should speak to an experienced bankruptcy attorney about your situation, included the value of the property, what happens under the circumstances you present in your question and other possible options, such as filing under Chapter 13 or debt negotiation.

There are many other factors in filing or not filing bankruptcy and you should discuss those in detail also.

No you cannot transfer your property to family in anticipation of filing BK, for 2 years, the trustee will void the transaction, and take the equity. The homestead exemption is $150,000, if your equity in your half is more than that, you don't need to file bk, but to work out arrangements with your credit card companies--most will give you an interest free plan if you go through a credit counseling company to do it.

Another possibility is for mother or you to take out a loan on the home to reduce your equity to $150,000 (reduce the overall equity to $300,000) If you own half. You can use the loan proceeds to pay expenses you would pay anyway, and to pay for exempt items, and put a lot in a retirement account, which most are exempt. The money you were able to make the credit card payments with can be put toward the mortgage payment. BK laws have many exemptions in personal property. You really need a pre-bankruptcy consultation with an attorney to go over these things.

Transferring property in order to avoid paying creditors could violate the Uniform Fraudulent Transfers Act, a criminal offense. A bankruptcy trustee can undo this transaction in a heartbeat, leaving you with absolutely no protection for your rights in this property. There are other, better options an experienced attorney can give you, but your do it yourself proposal is ill considered. Hope this perspective helps.

If you sell or give away property in the two-year period immediately before you file, you will have to disclose that transaction in your bankruptcy filing. Property given away in anticipation of a bankruptcy filing is still part of your estate, and the trustee has the legal authority to take it back.
Consult a bankruptcy attorney before you make a plan. Much of your equity could be exempt, or you may decide to file a Chapter 13 petition and later convert it to a Chapter 7 if possible.

Reclassifying this question to Chapter 7 Bankruptcy
I agree with the other attorney, this is more of a bankruptcy question. I will change the practice area for you.
This is more of a bankruptcy issue than a real estate issue, so you should consult with a bankruptcy attorney.
